title: What are the advantages of scientific research? - Quora

response.answer_text: Scientific research conducted in the pursuit of commercial profit refers to the creation of knowledge so that it can be used specifically for the acquisition of wealth, by its nature often done by private companies. This is in contrast to research conducted by governmental agencies which are usually non-profit, so that the information gained from research belongs to the people. This essay shall explore the merits and demerits of commercially oriented research. The basis of scientific research is gaining knowledge and in its use, often to improve the world. In both respects this commercially driven research proves to be superior, as research is done more efficiently and limited resources are focused on relevant places where its use is most needed. As such, commercial research often treads across moral boundaries. The lure of profits often cause scientists to override morality, Stem-cell research, for example, holds great potential for profits as a promise of an elixir of life, able to replace every part of the body and provide eternal youth. Such a technology would increase the life of many, as well as the wealth of the researchers. Unfortunately, it entails the destruction of life. Embryos, precursors to human babies, are destroyed to provide the stem-cells for the research. Some scientists have no qualms about this destruction of life, presumably for the advancement of science, but evidently for the pursuit of profit. Lastly, privatization of knowledge may impede scientific progress sometimes, instead of increasing the rate of research. Scientific research involves working on previous knowledge to create new knowledge. The invention of the printing press led to the Industrial Revolution as knowledge was more easily shared. With the privatisation of knowledge, scientific information becomes a currency to be closely guarded and not to be shared. As such, many companies working on similar projects waste resources to research repetitive information that has already been discovered, thus slowing down the overall rate of research.

Even non-scientists benefit from these, even if it’s only benefitting by a sense of awe and wonder.

We, as humans, are constantly observing our environment and reaching conclusions based on our own mental processing —which is, of course, the very base for shaping hypothesises— but unfortunately we are very limited by our personal opinions or lack of information, and our claims and ideas will be of no use, or perhaps not even correct, unless proved with proper research and reasoning. Conducting research (such as learning about the achievements and conclusions of others, gaining access to accurate data for further developments of the hypothesis, and reaching theories from the stated claims) is quite valuable for (1) improving our knowledge —which, for itself, drives innovation— and is also the best way of (2) identifying false claims and (3) directing our ideas towards useful paths. Because, as it is said, we are all scientists, we only need to learn to be researchers.

Scientific research unlike any other faculty of research is based on solid ground rules that make the studied phenomenon unbiased, reliable and objective. It is in general a good way to approach any novel hypothesis, discovery, idea or even a thought. It’s relevance can hence be seen in technological development that our world has achieved. This would not have been possible without rigorous scientific testing and rejection of hypotheses which forms the backbone of scientific research. Although the “General population” exploits the fruits of scientific research, they fail to understand its mechanism which is generally not exposed (unintentionally or intentionally) to them.
